article.authorLine: Niall M Mangan, Michael P Brenner
article.title: Correction: Systems analysis of the CO<sub>2</sub> concentrating mechanism in cyanobacteria

copyright.statement: This article is distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License, which permits unrestricted use and redistribution provided that the original author and source are credited.

authors.competingInterests: <label>Competing interests:</label>The authors declare that no competing interests exist.
<label>Competing interests:</label>The authors declare that no competing interests exist.

content.text: Mangan NM, Brenner MP. 2014. Systems analysis of the CO2 concentrating mechanism in cyanobacteria. eLife 3:e02043. doi: 10.7554/eLife.02043
Published 29 April 2014

We would like to issue the following corrections to our research article entitled, ‘Systems analysis of the CO<sub>2</sub> concentrating mechanism in cyanobacteria.’ The code used to generate the plots in the paper, mistakenly used 6.022 × 10<sup>22</sup> instead of 6.022 × 10<sup>23</sup> for Avogadro's number. This correction changes the quantitative numbers in the original paper but none of the conclusions are affected. Here are the corrected tables, figures, and text that changed. We thank Avi Flamholz for catching this error.
The article has been corrected accordingly. The original version published on 29 April 2014 is provided as Supplementary file 1 (file held on figshare under doi: 10.6084/m9.figshare.1352030).

content.title: Table 2. Enzymatic rates

content.text: We recalculated the enzymatic rates for carbonic anhydrase and RuBisCO. The values for V<sub>max</sub> and K<sub>1/2</sub> listed in the previous version of Table 2 used the incorrect 6.022 × 10<sup>22</sup> value for Avogadro's number. All plots in the original paper were for those values. All new plots are for the values listed in the updated table, using Avogadro's number 6.022 × 10<sup>23</sup>. The V<sub>max</sub> values are all about an order of magnitude lower than previously calculated.

tables:
Enzyme reactionactive siteskcat [1s]Vmax in ‘cell’ [μMs]Vmax in carboxysome [μMs]K1/2 [μM]
carbonic anhydrase hydration808 × 1048.8 × 1031.5 × 1073.2 × 103
carbonic anhydrase dehydration804.6 × 1041.5 × 1048.8 × 1069.3 × 103
RuBisCO carboxylation2160261781.8 × 105270

content.title: Figure 2. Phase space for HCO3− transport and carboxysome permeability

content.text: The main effect of correcting Avagadro's number is that the peak defining optimal carboxysome permeability is lower and broader. The optimal carboxhysome permeability for a target carboxysomal CO2 concentration is found by looking at the leftmost value on a line of constant concentration on the permeability vs HCO3− transport plot. This point represents the carboxysome permeability where the least amount of HCO3− transport is needed to achieve a given carboxysomal CO2 concentration. For 99% carboxylation (cyan curve below) this value is now around kc = 10−3 cm/s (previously kc = 6 × 10−3 cm/s). Carbonic anhydrase also saturates at a lower HCO3− transport value.

content.label: Figure 2.
content.title: Plotted are the parameter values at which the CO<sub>2</sub> concentration reaches some critical value.

caption.text: The leftmost line (dark blue) indicates for what values of jc and kc the CO2 concentration in the carboxysome would half-saturate RuBisCO (Km). The middle line (light blue) indicates the parameter values which would result in a CO2 concentration where 99% of all RuBisCO reactions are carboxylation reactions and only 1% are oxygenation reactions when O2 concentration is 260 μM. To the left of the line the error is greater and to the right it is smaller. The right most (red) line indicates the parameter values which result in carbonic anhydrase saturating. Here the rate of conversion from CO2 to HCO3−, α = 0, so there is no CO2 scavenging or facilitated uptake of CO2. The dotted line (grey) shows the kc and jc values, where the HCO3− concentration in the cytosol is 30 mM. The HCO3− concentration in the cytosol does not vary appreciably with kc in this parameter regime, and reaches 30 mM at jc≈0.6 cm/s. All other parameters, such as reaction rates are held fixed and the values can be found in the Tables 1 and 2.

content.title: Figure 2—figure supplement 1. Effect of decreased diffusion in the carboxysome

content.text: With the correction, decreasing the diffusion constant in the carboxysome has much less of an effect on the phase space plot. For optimal or larger carboxysome permeability, there is very little effect (kc ≥ 10−3 cm/s).

content.label: Figure 2—figure supplement 1.
content.title: Phase space for <math id="inf85"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> transport and carboxysome permeability for varying diffusion in the carboxysome.

caption.text: Solid lines show lines of constant CO<sub>2</sub> concentration in the carboxysome for <math id="inf86"><mrow><msub><mi>D</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mfrac></mrow></math>, or the diffusion constant of small molecule in water. Dashed lines show the same lines of constant CO<sub>2</sub> concentration, bur for <math id="inf87"><mrow><msub><mi>D</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mfrac></mrow></math>, or the diffusion constant of a small molecule in a 60% sucrose solution.

content.title: Figure 2—figure supplement 2. Effect of CO2 scavenging or facilitated uptake

content.text: The correction reduces the effect of facilitated uptake. At the optimal permeability it has nearly no effect (difference between dashed and solid lines near kc = 10−3 cm/s).

content.label: Figure 2—figure supplement 2.
content.title: Effect of CO2 scavenging or facilitated uptake on phase space for HCO3− transport, jc, and carboxysome permeability, kc.

caption.text: Plotted are the parameter values at which CO2 concentration reaches some critical value. The leftmost line (dark blue) indicates for what values of jc and kc the CO2 concentration in the carboxysome would saturate RuBisCO. The middle line (light blue) indicates the parameter values which would result in a CO2 concentration where 99% of all RuBisCO reactions are carboxylation reactions and only 1% are oxygenation reactions when O2 concentration is 260 μM. The rightmost (red) line indicates the parameter values which result in carbonic anhydrase saturating. Here α = 0 cm/s (solid lines) and α = 1 cm/s (dashed line), showing the effect of CO2 scavenging or facilitated uptake on the phase space. All other parameters, such as reaction rates are held fixed and the values can be found Table 1.

content.title: Figure 3. CO2 concentration in the carboxysome as function of HCO3− transport: comparison of numeric and analytic solutions

content.text: We plot Figure 3 assuming the new optimal carboxysome permeability of kc = 10−3 cm/s (previously kc = 6 × 10−3 cm/s). There is very little change from the previous Figure 3, with the updated carboxysome permeability. Had we plotted at the same kc = 6 × 10−3 cm/s, the CO2 would have been lower, because the system would not be at the optimal permeability.

content.label: Figure 3.
content.title: Numerical solution (diamonds and circles) and analytic solutions (carbonic anhydrase unsaturated, solid lines, and saturated, dashed lines) correspond well.

caption.text: HCO3− transport is varied, and all other system parameters are held constant. The CO2 concentration above which RuBisCO is saturated is Km (grey dashed line). The CO2 concentration where the oxygen reaction error rate will be 1% is C99% (grey dash-dotted line). The transition between carbonic anhydrase being unsaturated and saturated happens where the two analytic solutions meet (where the dashed and solid red lines meet). Below a critical value of transport, jc≈10−3 cm/s the level of transport is lower than the HCO3− leaking through the cell membrane. For these simulations and solutions the carboxysome permeability was kc = 10−3 cm/s (in previous version kc = 6 × 10−3 cm/s was used).

content.title: Figure 3—figure supplement 1. No effect of localizing carbonic anhydrase to the shell of the carboxysome

content.text: The correction did not at all effect the conclusion that the organization of carbonic anhydrase within the carboxysome has no effect on the resulting concentrations. Consistent with updated Figure 2—figure supplement 1, the effect of decreasing the diffusion in carboxysome is much less prominent than in the original manuscript.

content.label: Figure 3—figure supplement 1.
content.title: No effect of localizing carbonic anhydrase to the shell of the carboxysome.

caption.text: We assume the same amount of carbonic anhydrase and RuBisCO activity for each simulation and compare the case with the enzymes evenly distributed throughout the carboxysome to the case where the carbonic anhydrase is localized to the inner carboxysome shell. The (-.-) lines are for no organization and (x) for organized with Dc = 10−5 cm2/s. The (…) lines are for no organization and (o) are for organized with Dc = 10−5 cm2/s.

content.title: Figure 4. CO2 concentration in the carboxysome with varying carboxysome permeability

content.text: The correction does not effect the conclusion that an optimal carboxysome permeability exists, or what causes it, but it changes its absolute value. The correction has two main effects: (1) it decreases the optimal carboxysome permeability (seen as a shift in the peak) by a factor of 6, and (2) for carboxysome permeabilities higher than optimal (kc > 0.1 cm/s) the CO2 concentration is an order of magnitude lower. Therefore the optimal carboxysome permeability peak is at a lower kc value and more prominent.

content.label: Figure 4.
content.title: Concentration of CO<sub>2</sub> in the carboxysome with varying carboxysome permeability.

caption.text: (A) Numerical solution (diamonds and circles) and analytic solutions (carbonic anhydrase unsaturated, solid lines, and saturated, dashed lines) correspond well. On all plots CO2 (red circle) <HCO3− (blue diamond). Concentration in the cell along the radius, r, with carboxysome permeability kc = 10−5 cm/s (B), kc = 10−3 cm/s (C), kc = 1 cm/s (D). Grey dotted lines in (B), (C), (D) indicate location of the carboxysome shell boundary. The transition from low CO2 at high permeability (D) to maximum CO2 concentration at optimal permeability (C) occurs at kc=DRC=2 cm/s. At low carboxysome permeability (B) HCO3− diffusion into the carboxysome is slower than consumption. For all subplots the rate of CO2 to HCO3− conversion at the cell membrane, α = 0 cm/s and HCO3− uptake, jc = 0.6 cm/s. Qualitative results remain the same with varying jc, increasing α will increase the gradient of CO2 across the cell as CO2 is converted to HCO3− at the cell membrane.

content.title: Table 3. Fate of carbon brought into the cell for jc = 0.6 cm/s and kc = 1 × 10−3 cm/s

content.text: We updated the flux to the value at which cytosolic HCO3− is 30 mM and carboxysome permeability is optimal. Previously they were jc = 0.7 cm/s and kc = 6 × 10−3 cm/s.

content.label: Table 3.
content.title: Fate of carbon brought into the cell for jc = 0.6 cm/s and kc = 1 × 10−3 cm/s
Table 4. Fate of carbon brought into the cell for jc = 0.06 cm/s and kc = 1 × 10−3 cm/s

content.label: Table 4.
content.title: Fate of carbon brought into the cell for jc = 0.06 cm/s and kc = 1 × 10−3 cm/s
Discussion of fluxes and resulting 2-phosphoglycolate, and 3-phosphoglycerate production

content.text: The discussion of the number of transporters needed for this magnitude of <math id="inf34"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> influx increases by an order of magnitude from <math id="inf35"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mtext>transporters</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math> to <math id="inf36"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>4</mn></msup><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mtext>transporters</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>. While the change in uptake is less than a factor of two different, the conversion from picomoles/s to molecules/s for a cell used the incorrect value of Avogadro's number. So this is now about an order of magnitude larger than the number of ATP synthase complexes on the thylakoid membrane of spinach.

The numbers for net flux of HCO3− change slightly. For jc = 0.6 cm/s the net flux is 6×10−6pmolcell s compared to the previous value of 10−5pmolcell s and for jc = 0.06 cm/s the net flux is 9×10−7 pmolcell s compared with the previous value of 1×10−6 pmolcell s. So the conclusion that measured net fluxes of 10−6pmolcell s compares best with the lower HCO3− flux still holds.

Since Avagadro's number effects the rate of carboxylation and oxygenation, the recalculated values for 2-phosphoglycolate and 3-phosphoglycerate production are lower. This exacerbates the large amount of energy that appears to go into CO<sub>2</sub> concentration compared to the actual fixation. Now around 0.03% of concentrated inorganic carbon is fixed into 3-phosphoglycerate. Over 99.9% is lost to leakage either in the form of CO<sub>2</sub> or <math id="inf44"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> (previously these values were calculated to be 99%). The higher <math id="inf45"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> flux assumption (Table 3) predicts that only 217 2-phosphoglycolate are produced a second, and the lower <math id="inf46"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> flux assumption (Table 4) predicts that 1.4 × 10<sup>3</sup> 2-phosphoglycolate are produced a second. So the higher flux allows the production of many fewer 2-phosphoglycolate than previously estimated. Recalculating the time to fix the necessary carbon to replicate a cell results in 7–21 hr for the higher flux rate (Table 3) and 11–35 hr for the lower flux rate (Table 4). Both are consistant with the division times of cyanobacteria, but the higher flux rate is a better match.

In conclusion, the correction further highlights the puzzle of how much energy cyanobacteria must use <math id="inf47"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> to achieve a level of CO<sub>2</sub> which creates adequate fixation rates. Either cyanobacteria use a much larger amount of energy to achieve this internal concentration than to fix each CO<sub>2</sub>, the permeability of the cell must be much lower for <math id="inf48"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> than assumed here, or there is another mechanism not covered in this model.

content.title: Figure 5. Flux of HCO3− from varying sources as the proportion of CO2 to HCO3− outside the cell changes

content.text: The correction decreases the effect of CO2 scavenging at high permeabilities (kc = 1 cm/s and 10−2 cm/s). It now appears to be negligible compared to HOC3− uptake and CO2 uptake for all permeabilities. Only when CO2 concentration is a very small percentage of the external carbon, does the scavenging contribute more than the CO2 uptake, and both are far less than HCO3− uptake.

content.label: Figure 5.
content.title: Size of the <math id="inf49"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> flux in one cell from varying sources, as the proportion of CO<sub>2</sub> to <math id="inf50"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> outside the cell changes changes.

caption.text: We show results for three carboxysome permeabilities, kc, and only the scavenging is effected. Total external inorganic carbon is 15 μM, jc = 1 cm/s and αKα=1 cm/s. Scavenging is negligibly small for all values of kc shown. Unless there is very little HCO3− in the environment, HCO3− transport seems to be more efficient than CO2 facilitated uptake.

content.title: Figure 6. CO2 concentration with various organizations of enzymes in the cell

content.text: With the corrected Avagadro's number the CO<sub>2</sub> concentration is significantly lower in all but the optimal permeability case, making the error rate drastically higher. The effect of optimal permeability on CO<sub>2</sub> concentration is, therefore, much larger.

content.label: Figure 6.
content.title: Concentration of CO<sub>2</sub> achieved through various cellular organizations of enzymes, where we have selected the <math id="inf58"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> transport level such that the <math id="inf59"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> concentration in the cytosol is 30 mM.

caption.text: O2 concentration is 260 μM. The oxygenation error rates, as a percent of total RuBisCO reactions are indicated on the concentration bars. The cellular organizations investigated are RuBisCO and carbonic anhydrase distributed throughout the entire cytosol, co-localizing RuBisCO and carbonic anhydrase on a scaffold at the center of the cell without a carboxysome shell, RuBisCO and carbonic anhydrase encapsulated in a carboxysome with high permeability at the center of the cell, and RuBisCO and carbonic anhydrase encapsulated in a carboxysome with optimal permeability at the center of the cell.

content.title: Corrections to text

content.text: Throughout the text the default <math id="inf60"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> flux has been changed from <math id="inf61"><mrow><msub><mi>j</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.7</mn><mfrac><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mfrac></mrow></math> to <math id="inf62"><mrow><msub><mi>j</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.6</mn><mfrac><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mfrac></mrow></math> and optimal carboxysome permeability from <math id="inf63"><mrow><msub><mi>k</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mfrac><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mfrac></mrow></math> to <math id="inf64"><mrow><msub><mi>k</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mfrac><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mfrac></mrow></math>.

items.text: In the discussion of fluxes and concentrations we previously had written:

content.text: ‘Our simulated cell has a flux of 2 × 10<sup>7</sup> molecules/s. Assuming the rate of transport per transporter of <math id="inf65"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup><mfrac><mrow><mtext>molecules</mtext></mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mfrac></mrow></math> and our cell’s surface area this requires about <math id="inf66"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup><mfrac><mrow><mtext>transporters</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>. This is actually not that far off from the number of ATP synthase complexes on the thylakoid membrane in spinach, <math id="inf67"><mrow><mn>700</mn><mfrac><mrow><mtext>complexes</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math> (Miller and Staehelin, 1979), although it is still quite high.’

This is now: ‘Our simulated cell has a flux of 2 × 10<sup>8</sup>molecules/s. Assuming the rate of transport per transporter of <math id="inf68"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup><mfrac><mrow><mtext>molecules</mtext></mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mfrac></mrow></math> and our cell’s surface area this requires about <math id="inf69"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>4</mn></msup><mfrac><mrow><mtext>transporters</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>. This is about an order of magnitude higher than the number of ATP synthase complexes on the thylakoid membrane in spinach, <math id="inf70"><mrow><mn>700</mn><mfrac><mrow><mtext>complexes</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math> (Miller and Staehelin, 1979).’

items.text: In the discussion of fluxes and concentrations we previously had written:

content.text: ‘At the higher flux rate (Table 3) this means that a cell could replicate every 1–2 hr, so faster than cyanobacteria replicate. The lower flux rate (Table 4) would produce fix enough CO<sub>2</sub> for the cell to replicate every 8 to 21 hr, which is similar to the division times of cyanobacteria.’

This is now: ‘At the higher flux rate (Table 3) this means that a cell could replicate every 7–21 hr and the lower flux rate (Table 4) allows replication every 11 to 35 hr. Both are consistent with the division times of cyanobacteria.’

items.text: In the caption of Figure 5 we had written:

content.text: ‘When the carboxysome permeability is larger than optimal, kc = 1 cm/s, scavenging can contribute more than facilitated uptake at low external CO2 concentrations. However, when the carboxysome permeability at or below our geometric bound, kc <= 0.02 cm/s, scavenging is negligibly small.’
This is now: ‘Scavenging is negligibly small for all values of kc shown.’

items.text: In the text of the Benefit of CO<sub>2</sub> to <math id="inf71"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> conversion: facilitated uptake or scavenging of CO<sub>2</sub> we had written: ‘Scavenging only contributes significantly to total incoming <math id="inf72"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">−</mi></msubsup></mrow></math> when the carboxysome permeability is higher than optimal, Figure 5, and does not contribute significantly below our calculated upper bound of <math id="inf73"><mrow><msub><mi>k</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo><</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.02</mn><mi>c</mi><mi>m</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></math>. In these ranges for carboxysome permeability, there is very little CO2 leaking out of the carboxysome into the cytosol, so there is very little CO2 to scavenge, Figure 5.’

content.text: This is now: ‘Scavenging is negligibly small for all values of k<sub>c</sub> shown. There is very little CO<sub>2</sub> in the cytosol, so there is very little CO<sub>2</sub> to scavenge, Figure 5.’

items.text: There were also a few typos we have now corrected:

In the Reaction diffusion model section we had: ‘RuBisCO also requires ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate, the substrate which CO<sub>2</sub> reacts with to produce 3-phosphoglycolate.’ This has been corrected to ‘… CO<sub>2</sub> reacts with to produce 3-phosphoglycerate.’

in Table 1: ‘<math id="inf74"><mrow><msubsup><mi>k</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>H</mi></msubsup></mrow></math> permeability of cell membrane to CO<sub>2</sub>’ has been corrected to: ‘<math id="inf75"><mrow><msubsup><mi>k</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>H</mi></msubsup></mrow></math> permeability of cell membrane to <math id="inf76"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math>’.
Table 2 header said kcut which has been corrected to kcat.
In the Varying <math id="inf77"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> transport saturates enzyme section we had:

The chemical equilibrium is <math id="inf78"><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>, for pH around 7 (DeVoe and Kistiakowsky, 1961), so that <math id="inf79"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> > CO<sub>2</sub> in the carboxysome.

The equation is now: <math id="inf80"><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>V</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>V</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>.

The chemical equilibrium is <math id="inf78"><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>, for pH around 7 (DeVoe and Kistiakowsky, 1961), so that <math id="inf79"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> > CO<sub>2</sub> in the carboxysome.

The equation is now: <math id="inf80"><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>V</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>V</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>.
In Figure 3—figure supplement 1 the units for Dc on both the plot and caption are cm/s, they should be cm2/s.

In the Reaction diffusion model section we had: ‘RuBisCO also requires ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate, the substrate which CO<sub>2</sub> reacts with to produce 3-phosphoglycolate.’ This has been corrected to ‘… CO<sub>2</sub> reacts with to produce 3-phosphoglycerate.’

in Table 1: ‘<math id="inf74"><mrow><msubsup><mi>k</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>H</mi></msubsup></mrow></math> permeability of cell membrane to CO<sub>2</sub>’ has been corrected to: ‘<math id="inf75"><mrow><msubsup><mi>k</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>H</mi></msubsup></mrow></math> permeability of cell membrane to <math id="inf76"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math>’.
Table 2 header said kcut which has been corrected to kcat.
In the Varying <math id="inf77"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow></math> transport saturates enzyme section we had:
